Utterance: Hi, welcome back! How have you been since our last session?
Hey, I've been okay, I guess. Just trying to settle in more.
That's good to hear. Last time, we talked about your move to L.A. and how you were feeling a bit more depressed being away from friends and family. Have you noticed any changes in those feelings?
Yeah, I think it’s gotten a little better. I’ve been trying to connect with some people here, but it’s still tough.
Building new relationships can take time. What steps have you taken to connect with others?
Well, I joined a few online gaming communities. It feels a bit like home talking to people who share the same interests.
That sounds like a great way to find common ground. Have you met anyone in those communities that you feel you could connect with more personally?
A couple of people, yeah. We've been chatting a bit outside of the games, so that’s nice.
That’s a positive development! How does that make you feel?
It feels good. It's nice to talk to someone who gets my interests. Makes me feel less alone.
That’s wonderful! It sounds like you’re taking proactive steps to combat those feelings of loneliness. Have you been able to share how you feel with them?
Not really. I’m still a bit shy about opening up. I don’t want to scare them off.
Understandable. It can be intimidating to share personal feelings, especially with new acquaintances. What do you think holds you back from sharing?
I guess I worry they won’t understand or that they’ll think I’m being dramatic.
It’s common to have those worries. What if we explored some ways to express yourself that feel comfortable for you?
Sure, that sounds helpful.
One approach could be to start small—sharing lighter feelings or experiences before diving into deeper topics. How does that sound?
Yeah, I could try that. Maybe just talking about how I’m adjusting to L.A. would be a good start.
Exactly! It’s a great way to ease into deeper conversations. Have you had any experiences in L.A. recently that you could share with them?
Actually, I went to a local gaming café last week. It was fun to be around people who love games too.
That’s fantastic! How did that experience feel for you?
It felt really good. I was nervous at first, but once I got talking about games, it was like I found my groove.
That’s a great example of how you can connect with others through shared interests. What do you think you could do to replicate that feeling?
I guess I could try going to more events like that. Maybe even invite some of the people I’ve met online to join me.
That’s a brilliant idea! It could help strengthen those connections. Would you like to set a goal for the next week to try that?
Yeah, I think I’ll look up some events. Maybe even a game night.
Perfect! Setting that goal can help you take a step forward. How do you feel about the idea of reaching out to invite someone?
A bit anxious, but I think I can do it.
That’s completely normal. Remember, it’s okay to feel anxious. You can also practice what you might say if that helps ease your nerves.
Good idea. I’ll write it down.
Great! Writing it down can help clarify your thoughts. Is there anything else on your mind that you want to talk about today?
Well, I’ve been thinking about my family a lot lately. I miss them.
That’s understandable. Being away from family can be really tough. How do you cope with those feelings?
I try to call them when I can. It helps, but it’s not the same as being there.
It’s definitely not the same, but it’s great that you’re making an effort to stay connected. What do you enjoy talking about with them?
Mostly just catching up on life. I tell them about my job hunt and they share what’s going on back home.
It sounds like those conversations are meaningful for you. Have you considered scheduling regular calls, like a weekly check-in?
Yeah, I think I’ll do that. It would give me something to look forward to.
That’s a wonderful idea! It can help maintain that connection and lessen feelings of loneliness.
Thanks, Ellie. I appreciate the suggestions.
Of course! I’m here to support you. Before we wrap up, is there anything else you’d like to discuss or any questions you have?
No, I think I’m good. I feel like I have some things to work on now.
I’m glad to hear that! Remember, progress takes time, and you’re doing great. Let’s meet again next week to check in on how things are going.
Sounds good! See you then.
Take care, and I look forward to hearing about your week.
Bye!
